author: Syed Muthahar Saqaf
text:
Noted vocalist T. N. Seshagoapalan presenting SeethaKalyanam Harikatha at the Ramayanam Festival in Salem on Sunday.— Photo: E. Lakshmi Narayanan

The week-long Ramayanam Festival titled “Varna Kalanjiyam” got under way in the city on Sunday with a Harikatha on ‘Seetha Kalyanam’ by noted vocalist T. N. Seshagopalan.

The Ramayanam Festival is being organised jointly by the Tamil Nadu Iyal Isai Nataka Manram and the State Department of Art and Culture with the objective of promoting the epic among the younger generation through various musical forms.

S. Soundappan, Mayor, inaugurated the festival in the presence of B. Hemanathan, Regional Assistant Director of Art and Culture.

Mr. Hemanathan said that the State Government sanctioned funds for conducting the festival for two weeks in Chennai and Salem. Musical exponents from across the State presented various performances during the first phase of the festival held in Chennai recently. The Chennai event evoked overwhelming response, he said and expressed the hope that the programmes in Salem would attract all sections of society.

Seshagopalan rendered Kambaramayanam lyrics, followed by the Ramanatakam songs penned by Arunachala Kavirayar. He also rendered ‘Seetha Kalyana Vaibohame’ keerthanas of legendary Thiagarajar.

Seshagopalan also rendered the verses “Pachai Maamalai pol maeni...” from Naalayira Divya Prabandam to explain the significance of Seetha Kalyanam.

He explained the events that marked the marriage of Lord Rama and Seetha such as the absence of groom’s father during the marriage and the role of Viswamithrar in solemnising the marriage as introduction to the songs connected to these sequences.

T. N. S. Krishna, son of Seshagopalan, and ‘Madurai’ R. Rajaram rendered able vocal support throughout the Harikatha. Seshagopalan was accompanied by V. V. Ravi on violin, Guru Ragavendran on mridangam and P. Srikrishnan on harmonium.

The Ramayanam Festival will be on till February 27.
title: Promoting Ramayanam among younger generation
